Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Story: It was past midnight when my phone buzzed. I answered, hearing my friend’s shaky voice on the other end. She was crying, barely able to get the words out about her family’s tragedy. I sat up, heart pounding, listening as she poured out her pain. I wanted to comfort her, to be the friend she needed—someone who listened, who offered warmth and understanding. But my mind kept drifting back to the networking event earlier that evening, where a colleague had pressed me for details about a client’s case. I’d dodged the question, but the pressure lingered. Now, as my friend sobbed, she mentioned a name—one that matched my client’s. My roles collided: as a friend, I wanted to help, to share what I knew; as a lawyer, I was bound by confidentiality. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt torn, caught between loyalty and duty, unsure which part of myself to honor.
